result.execSummary:
The defendant Nicholas J Todd was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of Narcotic Drugs, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(am).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Defendant IS eligible for Challenge Incarceration and Substance Abuse Program after 2 years of initial confinement.
Credit time is to be determined at later time.

superMiscConds.notes:
Court costs and DNA to be paid as a Condition of Extended Supervision.

If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.
Maintain full time employement and/or school.
Submit to an AODA Assessment and follow through with any treatment recommended.
Mental Health evaluation and treatment deemed appropriate.

Maintain absolute sobriety.
Submit to random alcohol/drug screens.
Not to use or possess of alcohol or controlled substances without a valid prescription or any drug paraphernalia.
Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed.
Inform Agent of all prescriptions.
Follow through with any treatment/counseling recommended.
No association with known drug users or dealers and no contact at any place where illegal drugs are purchased, used, stored, packaged or distributed.
Anger Management counseling.
Provide DNA sample if not already provided.

Defendant Nicholas J Todd in court, in custody, with attorney J Anthony Rosario.   Kristi J Gordon appeared for the State of Wisconsin.    The Defendant was sentenced to the following:

IMPOSED SENTENCE of: 

3 YEARS IMPRISONMENT (CREDIT - TO BE DETERMINED -  ATTORNEY'S TO FILE REQUEST WITH THE COURT)
to begin forthwith.
  -  1 YEAR OF INITIAL CONFINEMENT
  -  2 YEAR(S) OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION;

CONDITIONS OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION:  
*AODA Assessment and follow through with any treatment recommended;
*Absolute Sobriety;  Random U.A.'s ; 
*No Use or Possession of alcohol, controlled substances or drug paraphernalia.
*No Use or Possession of prescription drugs without a valid prescription;
*Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed.
*Inform Agent of all prescriptions
*Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent;
*Maintain full time employment and/or combination of schooling 
*No association with known drug users or dealers and no contact at any place where illegal drugs are purchased, used, stored, packaged, or distributed.
*Mental Heath evaluation and treatment deemed appropriate.
*100 hours community service.  on both sentences? 
*Anger Management Counseling. 
*Provide DNA sample if not already provided. 

COSTS: $268.00 (to be paid as a condition of probation);
DNA: $250.00 (to be paid as a condition of probation);


Defendant is eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program. (after two years initial confinement)
Defendant is eligible for Substance Abuse Program. (after two years initial confinement)
